Russian President Vladimir Putin speaks at a meeting with Interior Ministry officials in Moscow, Russia, Friday, March 21, 2014. President Vladimir Putin completed the annexation of Crimea on Friday, signing the peninsula into Russia at nearly the same time his Ukrainian counterpart sealed a deal pulling his country closer into Europe's orbit. (AP Photo/RIA-Novosti, Mikhail Klimentyev, Presidential Press Service) ORG XMIT: MOSB107 (Photo: Mikhail Klimentyev AP) Story Highlights Finance minister Wolfgang Schaeuble says Russian President Vladimir Putin's tactics resemble HItler's

German Chancellor Angela Merkel called Russia's annexation of Crimea a violation of international law

Russia's Prime Minister Dmitry Medvedev visited Crimea on Monday

BERLIN (AP) — Germany's influential finance minister says Russian President Vladimir Putin's annexation of Crimea employed tactics reminiscent of those used by Adolf Hitler to expand Germany's territory before World War II.

Wolfgang Schaeuble told a school group visiting his ministry Monday that Putin's contention that Russian nationals were at risk in Crimea was like Hitler's claim that ethnic Germans were being discriminated against in the Sudetenland region of Czechoslovakia before Germany annexed it in 1938, the DPA news agency reported.

"Hitler already took over the Sudetenland with such methods," Schaeuble said at the public event, though he added that he was not comparing Russia to Nazi Germany.

Chancellor Angela Merkel refused to comment on the remarks, saying only that she saw the Russian annexation of Crimea as a "violation of international law."

title: German minister compares Crimea to Sudetenland
